{"step_by_step_thinking": "Juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma is a highly vascular tumor that can cause significant bleeding during surgery. To determine the main vessel involved in bleeding from Juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma, we can refer to the relevant documents. Document [14] states that all tumors had primary supply from the distal third of the ipsilateral internal maxillary artery (IMA). Document [20] mentions that the tumors were supplied by a greater number of feeding vessels, including the Vidian branch of the internal carotid artery (ICA). Based on this information, the main vessel involved in bleeding from Juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma is the internal maxillary artery (IMA).", "answer_choice": "C"}
